data.source: 2003 Programme for International Student Assessment (PISA) dataset (OECD student assessment survey)
data.unit_of_analysis: Individual student (Level 1), nested within schools (Level 2), nested within countries (Level 3)
data.notes: Mathematics self-concept measured with five Likert items (Cronbach’s alpha ≈ .88) and standardized (range approximately -2.24 to 2.48). Student ability estimated using PISA plausible values with analyses conducted separately for each plausible value. Numerous moderators from SES and academic self-regulation constructs were included. Large sample size; emphasis on practical significance alongside statistical significance (e.g., effects < .075 given little weight).

method.description: The study used three-level multilevel modeling of PISA 2003 data to test the Big-Fish-Little-Pond Effect (BFLPE) on mathematics self-concept and to examine moderation by socioeconomic status and academic self-regulation constructs. Mathematics self-concept was measured with a reliable scale, student ability was modeled using PISA plausible values, and interactions between school-average ability and multiple moderators were tested. Factor analyses and correlational analyses were used to evaluate constructs and relationships. Statistical significance thresholds were stringent due to the large sample, and effect sizes were interpreted for practical importance.
steps: Obtain and prepare PISA 2003 student, school, and country-level data.
Compute mathematics self-concept scores from five Likert items; standardize scores.
Estimate student mathematics ability using PISA plausible values; run analyses separately for each plausible value.
Construct school-average mathematics ability to capture the BFLPE context.
Specify a three-level multilevel model (students nested in schools nested in countries).
Include individual ability (linear and quadratic terms), school-average ability, and proposed moderators (SES and self-regulation constructs).
Test interactions between school-average ability and each moderator to assess moderation of the BFLPE.
Evaluate model fit, statistical significance (with p < .001 for interactions), and interpret effect sizes for practical significance.
Summarize moderator effects and robustness of the BFLPE across constructs.
method.models: Three-level multilevel linear models with random effects (students within schools within countries), including interactions between school-average ability and moderators; regression analyses conducted per plausible value of ability; exploratory and confirmatory factor analyses for construct validation; correlational analyses among key variables.
method.independent_variables: Individual mathematics ability (linear and quadratic), school-average mathematics ability (BFLPE indicator), socioeconomic status indicators (parental education and occupation, home educational resources, cultural possessions), academic self-regulation constructs (intrinsic and extrinsic motivation, self-efficacy, learning strategies including elaboration, memorization, and control strategies), mathematics anxiety, social orientations (cooperative and competitive), student–teacher relations, sense of belonging.

results.summary: The study found strong evidence for the Big-Fish-Little-Pond Effect: higher school-average mathematics ability was associated with lower mathematics self-concept for equally able students. The BFLPE was broadly robust across countries and across many student characteristics. Positive student–teacher relationships and a greater sense of school belonging were associated with higher self-concepts and appeared to alleviate the BFLPE to some extent. Anxiety was negatively related to self-concept and exacerbated the BFLPE. Learning strategies such as elaboration were positively related to self-concept, while reliance on memorization showed an adverse interaction with school-average ability. Motivational variables (intrinsic and extrinsic) and self-efficacy were positively related to self-concept, but generally did not substantively moderate the BFLPE. SES had weak positive associations with self-concept and minimal moderation of the BFLPE.

numerical_results.outcome_name: Effect of school-average ability (BFLPE) on mathematics self-concept
Individual mathematics ability (linear) on mathematics self-concept
Individual mathematics ability (quadratic) on mathematics self-concept
Memorization strategies on mathematics self-concept (main effect)
Sense of belonging on mathematics self-concept

metadata.original_paper_title: Big-Fish-Little-Pond Effect: Generalizability and Moderation—Two Sides of the Same Coin
